answers.text:
Hello Michael,
Planning 5-20 years ahead is a difficult process, but I found some resources that might help your city along the way.
The Maryland National Parks and Planning Commission has put out a study detailing their service plans all the way to 2040:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/301041/Using_Vision_and_New_Tools_to_Drive_Services_for_2010_and_Beyond
California law requires cities and counties to adopt long-term plans.   This is the document from the city of Pleasanton, which includes planning for open spaces, land use, and public facilities:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/5287/Pleasanton_General_Plan_2005__2025
This is the City of Alameda's long-term economic plan.  It is a tremendous document outlining the current progress on the economic plan as well as future plans for growth:
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/102102/CITY_OF_ALAMEDA_ECONOMIC_DEVELOPMENT_STRATEGIC_PLAN_UPDATE
I hope these help Aurora effectively predict its spacing needs far down the road.
Gabe Brehm
Knowledge Network Intern
ICMA

author: Michael Edwards
text: The City of Auburn is interested in hearing about any long-range studies any cities have undertaken to help plan for the facilities needed to support future growth in your government services.  We have continued to experience strong growth over the last decade and have a very active and effective economic development function, so we anticipate to continue to grow.  We are approaching capacity at several facilities, and while we have some plans for those services that are suited to satellite locations (fire stations, police substations, etc..) we are concerned with the space needs for our more centralized activities (Finance, HR, City Manager, IT etc...).  We would like to be able to identify our future land and plant needs to ensure we have sufficient space 5-20 years down the road to expand as needed.  Have any cities undertaken a comprehensive, long-range facilities plan that looks at these issues, as well as inventories existing assets in this context?
title: Long-range facilities planning
